pages.text: Cyanorus singularis comes from the Upper Ediacaran, with fossils found from the White Sea, Russia. It is a elongated proarticulatan, growing up to 1 cm in overall length. It is currently the only proarticulatan to be accepted to have internal structures, something very rarely preserved in Precambrain rocks.

The generic name derives from the English word 'Cyan', which further derives from the Greek word 'kúanos', to mean 'Blue'; and the Greek word 'óros', to mean 'mountain'. The specific name derives from the directly from the Latin word 'singularis', to mean 'singular' or 'peculiar'.
